sub_topic: The construction of the Heighway dragon curve.
message_1: What is the total length of the Heighway dragon curve of order 6, if each unit square of the curve has a side length of 2 cm? (Assuming the curve starts and ends at the same point.)
message_2:
The Heighway dragon curve is a fractal curve that can be constructed by repeatedly folding a strip of paper in half, and then unfolding it so that each fold creates a 90-degree angle. The order of the curve refers to the number of times the paper is folded.

The total length of the Heighway dragon curve of order n can be calculated using the formula:

Length = (side length of unit square) × (2^n)

In this case, the side length of each unit square is 2 cm, and the order of the curve is 6. So, we can calculate the total length as follows:

Length = 2 × (2^6) = 2 × 64 = 128 cm

Therefore, the total length of the Heighway dragon curve of order 6 with a side length of 2 cm for each unit square is 128 cm.
